review.title: A Survey of Arabic Dialogues Understanding for Spontaneous Dialogues and Instant Message
review.abstract: Building dialogues systems interaction has recently gained considerable attention, but most of the resources and systems built so far are tailored to English and other Indo-European languages. The need for designing systems for other languages is increasing such as Arabic language. For this reasons, there are more interest for Arabic dialogue acts classification task because it a key player in Arabic language understanding to building this systems. This paper surveys different techniques for dialogue acts classification for Arabic. We describe the main existing techniques for utterances segmentations and classification, annotation schemas, and test corpora for Arabic dialogues understanding that have introduced in the literature

sections.heading: 2. CONCEPTS AND TERMINOLOGIES
sections.text: In this section, the concepts related to language understanding that are used in this essay are presented.

sections.heading: 2.1. Dialogue Act
sections.text: The terminology of speech acts was treated by Searle (1969) on the basis of the Austin work (1962) as follows (Webb, 2010): assertively, they oblige the speaker to be truthful about a proposal (e.g., assertion, assertion, reporting, announcement) Guidelines that attempt to achieve some effect through the listener's action (e.g., commands, pleading, requesting, begging) Commissions oblige the speaker to act in the future (e.g., promise, offering, swearing, doing something) Expressive are the expression of a psychological state (e.g., thanking, apologizing, congratulating) Explanations are speech acts whose successful execution brings about the consistency between the content of the statement and reality (e.g., resignation, condemning, dismissal, and baptism) Dialogue acts are roughly the equivalent of Searle's speech act (1969). Dialogue acts differ in different dialog systems (dialogue systems closely related to the 1999 work), which treat the term "dialogues" as the most important dialogues.

sections.heading: 2.2. Turn vs Utterance
sections.text: In the natural human conversation, we refer to the speaker's speaking time and refer to the ability to know when we start and when we finish the turn in the conversion. The turn limit contains one or more sentences, in addition, "turning" is generally fixed to the expression of a single sentence. In the spoken dialogue system, the term enunciation refers to the one speech act. (Dream and Heeman, 1997) defines the unit of expression by one or more of the following factors: 1. Speech by a single speaker, speaking without interruption by the speech of the other, as a single turn. 2. Has syntactic and / or semantic completion. 3. Defines a single speech act. 4. Is an intonational phrase. 5. Separated by a pause. Consequently, this paper refers to an enunciation as a small unit of speech corresponding to a single turn (Webb, 2010; Dream and Heeman, 1997).

sections.heading: 2.3 Dialectal Arabic
sections.text: There are three categories of Arabic: Classical Arabic "The Ancient Written Form," Modern Standard Arabic (MSA) "The Famous Written Form Today" and Dialectal Arabic "Arab Mother Languages of Arabic Speakers" (Diab and Habash, 2007).In addition, the written form of the Arabic language - MSA - is completely different from dialectical Arabic. However, MSA is primarily used in written form, but the regional dialects are predominant in spoken communication or in daily use. Unlike MSA, the dialects have no written grammar rules and have different characteristics, such as morphology, syntax and phonetics. Dialectal Arabic can mainly be divided into six dialect groups: Maghrebi, Egyptian, Levantine, Gulf, Iraq and others. These regional dialects of Arabic are quite different from each other. Egyptian dialect, commonly known as Egyptian slang, is the most widely understood Arabic (Zaidan and Burqan).
